text: Thompson's stride is slowed by the eighty-pound suit...He CLUNKS down the road. Dust clouding from his boots...
He moves past the same mounds of charred and rotting stuf inner tubes, soda bottles, crumpled cans, steaming animal waste, and bits of fluttering plastic that the bot passed
The question is not - do you see a white garbage bag? It' which of these bags is the BOMB?
Sweat slides down into his eyes.
200 meters. It's boiling in here.   UPRANGE
Copy that. 200 meters.
The RASP of Thompson's BREATHING loud on Sanborn's walkie talkie...   DOWNRANGE
Thompson walks on.
A knot of flies floats in the air in front of his helmet. lifts an arm and they disappear.
The desert sun glints off a nearby car and momentarily bleaches his mask bright white.
A YOUNG GIRL with an INFANT BABY in her arms appears in a off doorway, then withdraws out of sight.
He looks down, CAREFULLY watches his footfalls.   Garbage piled on top of garbage.   UPRANGE
Eldridge and Sanborn are at the ready, scanning the area watching Thompson.
One hundred.
Copy, that. 100 meters out.   DOWNRANGE
Thompson: careful footfalls on sand.
Breathing. Heat.   Sun.   Sweat.   Flies.
Suddenly a DOG out of nowhere charges, BARKING ferociousl
Thompson is momentarily startled.    Then resumes his wal The dog runs off.
Thompson blinks more sweat out of his eyes.
Twenty five.
Sanborn lifts the walkie.   Sweat in his eyes.   Wipes it
Copy twenty five. You're in the kill zone.
Thanks for reminding me.
Eldridge nods.   Everything progressing nice and easy.
Thompson is standing over the blasting cap.
Alright. I'm here. I'm gonna put it in.
Copy that.
Thompson picks the blasting cap off the ground and looks
As distant THUMP of approaching chopper wash quickly beco super loud in his ears.
Hold on. Bird coming in.
I hear it.
Thompson pulls the cap back out. He looks up to see the g black shape passing over him.
[Note: we see now what Thompson is worried about: as it c the air, a helicopter rotor produces static electricity. see this electricity as a faint, nearly transparent rippl wave.]
Guy is trying to kill me.
The helicopter turns, and swings back around.
If he brings that electricity back here, I'm going to put a bullet in his tail.
The helicopter banks in the other direction, away from Thompson.   UPRANGE
A collective sigh of relief.
Jesus. (into walkie) I think he figured out we were EOD. You're good, Blaster One.   DOWNRANGE
Thompson inserts the cap back into the C4.
We're armed and ready to blow, Blaster Mike.
Copy that. You coming back?
Copy that, I'm on my way.
Thompson gets up. Looks around at the expanse of empty, s road under heavy guard.
The war has stopped for him -- and he knows it.
Thompson begins to walk back uprange, looking carefully a the ground around him.   UPRANGE
Sanborn and Eldridge lower their rifles.   DOWNRANGE
Thompson carefully nudges a Coke can out of the way of hi boots.   UPRANGE
Eldridge turns away from Thompson and opens the HUMVEE tr to stow the bot.
Sanborn swats a fly and takes a sip of water.
Eldridge loads the bot. Out of the corner of his eye he s some movement in the butcher shop.
Hey Sanborn --
Yeah?
Butcher shop - dude has a phone.
He shouldn't be --
Eldridge is already moving towards the store.
Sanborn raises his gun and puts it on the store. The back Eldridge moving in and out of his scope. He can't get a shot.
(shouting, waving his gun) Hey - put that down--
The BUTCHER in a white apron nods and puts up his hand as to say, `give me a minute.'     THOMPSON
--walking towards the Humvee away from the bomb. Lumberin steps.
50 meters. Why is Eldridge running?   ELDRIDGE  --RUNNING HARD--
Hey - put the phone down!   SANBORN
--bolting sideways trying to get Eldridge out of his line SIGHT--
(shouting to Eldridge)        PUT THE PHONE DOWN! Burn him!   ELDRIDGE
--legs pumping, his thumb flicks the rifle safety--
The butcher smiles. Gives Eldridge the thumbs up sign. Hi other thumb is jamming a button on the phone.
Now Eldridge is panicked, shouting:
DROP THE PHONE!!!   THOMPSON
--starts to run.   Fear in his eyes.   BUTCHER
--smiles back at Eldridge--
MACRO: thumb on send button of the cell phone.     THOMPSON
--running full out now--  BOOM ---
- Fireball blasts out from the bomb
-- flattening Thompson
-- Blood splatters the inside of his helmet.
-- thick cloud of particulate matter roils out in slow mo
-- hitting Eldridge and Sanborn -- turning them black.
With the roiling cloud we begin to float up and out over entire city of Baghdad:

--we see intersections jammed with traffic; American Humv and tanks idle next to red-and-white taxis, beat-up Opals the military and civilian mixed up in one snarling line, competing for space, advantage...
--we continue to rise until we take in the entire massive metropolis. Mosques and office towers ascend from a maze dusty streets teeming with life despite two decades of wa
The roiling black cloud thins in a light breeze and we ha CUT TO:  BLACK
A shaft of afternoon sun creeps past a plywood-covered window, faintly lighting the interior of a narrow, low- ceilinged room.
In the dimness we see contours: desk, chair, a large lock and the silhouette of a MAN moving a cot away from the window. On the cot is a small duffle bag.
We hear a knock from the outside.
The man moving the cot stops.
Yeah.
Sergeant James?
It's open.
The door opens and in the light we see Sanborn.
Sergeant James. (extending his hand) J.T. Sanborn. Welcome to Bravo Company and welcome to Camp Victory.
Victory? I thought this was called Camp Liberty.
They changed it last week. Victory sounds better.
It's Will. Good to meet you J.T.

SERGEANT WILLIAM JAMES extends a hand. A former DELTA soldier is in his late twenties, good-looking, appealing face, solid build, one of the lucky ones. And yet, look closer. In the right light, there's an unusual depth to h expression, to his eyes and all-American face, as if he's guarding an inner chaos that could rush out at any time.
Right now, however, James is doing his best to act like a regular nice guy.
Sanborn looks around the empty room.   One duffle.
So, is that all you brought from Kabul?
James motions to the locker.
Yeah. Here, give me a hand with this.
Sanborn helps James move the locker against the wall.
By the window.
They push the locker over the window, blocking the light. It's very dark in the room now.

A mortar once hit near my trailer -- boom -- a two inch piece of frag cut through the aluminum and flew this far (gesturing with his hands) over my head, past my balls and landed in my computer hard-drive. Where's the damn light?
Sanborn finds the switch in the corner. Then he comes bac and taps the metal locker, testing its strength.
This should stop any lateral pieces.
Yeah, I'm good unless it comes through the roof (smiles) in which case I'm gonna need a closed casket.
Sanborn doesn't like the joke, tries to change gears.
The accent -- you from Georgia?
Tennessee.     Trailer park off I-5.
Oh, right. I'm from Vermont. You know, "live free or die." Trees. Snow. Maple syrup. Pot.
James gives him a polite smile.
Sanborn soldiers on:
Well, if you need anything to get squared away, just let me know. Either myself or Owen -- Eldridge -- be happy to steer you in the right direction for supplies, whatever.
Okay. (pause) Thanks.
Anyway, the mess tent can be hard to find the first time ... so ... if you want ... we're going over there now to grab chow ... come along.
Thanks. But no.
You want me to bring you back a burger or something?
(shaking his head) Nah. I'm good.
James unzips his duffle and gets up to put his clothes on overhead shelf. Sanborn watches him, then starts for the door. James turns to face Sanborn.
I'm sorry about Thompson, I heard he was a good tech.
Yeah, he was. And he was a good team leader too.
I know I can't fill his shoes, but I'm here to try--
Appreciate it.
--but you know, if it's your time it's your time. No man can change that.
Yeah, I guess that's true.
So, we roll at oh-six-hundred.
James smiles slightly as he contemplates the next day's mission.
Looking forward to it.
Sanborn comes out and sees Eldridge, who has been waiting the door.
They walk towards the mess tent. Sanborn is absorbed in thought. Eldridge doesn't want to interrupt.
After a moment.
So?
A good `ole boy. You know, loves the Army, blood runs green. Country boy. Seems solid.
I always liked southerners, for some reason.
Then he's just your type.
Why is it always the gay jokes with you. It's not even funny.
(growing serious, he imitates James' accent) It's your time it's your time.
He said that?
Sanborn nods.

head_text.subj: EXT CAMP VICTORY ELDRIDGE'S TRAILER EARLY MORNING

text: The sand has completed its daily march across Eldridge's steps. His boots sweep a bit away as he steps outside in battle gear, and kisses a photo of the Virgin Mary and sl it inside his helmet. He steps out into the bright mornin sun.

head_text.subj: EXT CAMP VICTORY HUMVEE PARKING LOT

text: Sanborn is gearing up, strapping on a shitload of weapons ammunition. Ready for anything.
Eldridge comes up.
Where's the FNG?
[Note: FNG. Fucking New Guy.]
Eldridge, surprised to see James is not outside ready to knocks on his door.
Beat.
Yeah?
It's oh-six-hundred.
The door opens a crack, revealing James dressed in his skivvies and wrapped in a blanket, blinking awake.
Gimme a minute.
Before Eldridge can express the shock that's written all his face, James has closed the door.
An American Humvee drives past a long line of parked tank arranged in a neat rows, and gathering dust on all horizo surfaces.   INT HUMVEE
Sanborn is behind the wheel, simultaneously driving and loading his rifle. James sits next to him in the passenge seat, loading his rifle and looking out the window. Eldri is in the back seat.

(looking out window) Those Abrams have been parked ever since I got here nine months ago, and I ain't seen them move once. They should put those on eBay. Hey, J.T., how much you think one of those would cost?
Ten million?

Well I guess it makes sense. Anybody comes alongside the Humvee, we're dead. Anybody looks at you funny, you're dead. Pretty much, the bottom line, is if you're in Iraq you're dead. How's a tank going to stop that?
Gimme a break, Owen.
Sorry. Just trying to scare the new guy.
The Humvee moves out of the base and into the outskirts o the city. Heat and sand and little else.   INT   HUMVEE
We had a few bombs up in Kabul too.
Sure, I bet you did. But you're going to be real busy here, boss.
James smiles, settles back in the seat.   EXT   HUMVEE
The Humvee is now approaching a cluster of cars.     INT   HUMVEE
Hey Owen -- watch the fucking road.
Eldridge moves up to the gunner's seat on top of the Humv   EXT   HUMVEE
Eldridge has a collection of rocks he keeps in the gunner nest and now he throws one at the car in front of him. Th passenger turns around.
Imshee -- Imshee !
The Humvee grinds to a stop on the outskirts of town. It' place teeming with trash, with dwellings that look as bea down as the people. The ghetto of the ghetto.
James is first out, Sanborn comes up behind him.
Eldridge climbs out of the turret.
They are now out in the open -- standing on Iraqi sand -- where anything can happen.
Clear here.
Eldridge nods and begins turning suspicious bits of plast over with the tip of his boots.
Clear here.
(looking around at the
Where are the guys who called this in?
James walks on. Sanborn and Eldridge exchange a glance `w the hell,' and follow him.
Victory Main, Victory Main, this is Blaster Mike. Interogative, Do you have an updated poz for the link- up? Has their position changed?
After a moment a scratchy voice over his walkie.
Blaster Mike, this is Victory Main. Negative. Figures to follow. Three- four-five-three is your grid. You should have a visual on them right now. They're waving an American
Sanborn keys his GPSw unit.
Negative, Main. No one in sight.
Blaster Mike. You should have a visual, waving a flag.
(looking at empty space) Well, that's were I am and I don't see any guys in fatigues, and I sure as hell don't see any American flag, Over.
James, Sanborn and Eldridge continue their slow walk down street. An empty Humvee comes into view.
They abandoned their vehicle?
James walks forward. Unconcerned. Takes out a cigarette a lights it. Sanborn's walkie comes to life.
Roger, Blaster. I copied you the first time.
James approaches the empty Humvee.
Stops. Turns to see a tiny American flag being waved in t window of a nearby building. James jogs over to the build opens the door.
Hello boys --
Looking into a room full of SOLDIERS who are trying not t look afraid.
Yeah, thanks. Roger that.
Don't tell me the bomb is in there with you.
A SERGEANT, slightly embarrassed, climbs out into the ope and tries to act nonchalant.
He points down the block, which is a sea of trash and whi plastic bags.
(pointing far down the
Down on that block, one of our informants says there is an IED in a white plastic bag.
James has heard enough and even though the Sergeant may h more to say --
I'll get it. (turning to Sanborn) Break out the suit. (turning back to the
Keep your guys back.
Sanborn is already unloading the robot.
What about the bot?
Don't need it.
What? Aren't we going to send the bot down to take a look?
Nah, I'm going to take care of it.
Sanborn shoots Eldridge a look. Is he an FNG or what?
JAMES
Sanborn and Eldridge kneeling before James, buckling on t suit.
I was thinking if we sent the bot down first --
James ignores him.
As soon as he's enclosed in the suit, James moves quickly toward the rubble pile.   UPRANGE
He's a rowdy boy.
He's reckless.
Somebody should tell the U.N. to send the rice in clear plastic bags so there's no place to hide the IEDs. The insurgent would be like, `Allah has forsaken me all the bags are clear'.
[Note: IED Improvised Explosive Device. A homemade bomb. number one weapon of the Iraqi insurgency.]
I've seen so much garbage I'm starting to like the smell.  JAMES
As he advances downrange, he passes a line of bushes and tosses an incendiary grenade at it, setting the foliage ablaze.  UPRANGE
Sanborn looks on in confusion.
Blaster One, what are you doing?
No answer.
Blaster One, this is Blaster Mike, what's with the fire on the side of the road, over?
No answer. Sanborn and Eldridge struggle to get a visual. They dash to a better vantage point.
Hey James, can you hear me? What's with the fire on the side of the road, over?  JAMES  FINALLY:
Creating a diversion.
Sanborn can barely see James through the flames and smoke  UPRANGE
He climbs up on top of the Humvee to get a better look bu gets only a partial view.
From what? Is there a threat?
Eldridge scans the area with his rifle, tense, trying to figure out how to behave.
Get up on that wall.
Eldridge hustles over to the wall, but can't manage to pu himself up with all his gear on, so dashes down to a moun dirt, which gives him a leg up.
James, I can't see you, over.
The last thing he expects is James' laconic reply:
Copy that.
Sanborn shoots Eldridge a look - what the fuck.
Tell me what you see, Specialist.
Eldridge, on the wall, feels awfully vulnerable and in th open. The wall is quite narrow. His feet are precariously balanced. His view of James is not much better
I see his back. He's walking downrange. Oh, I lost him.
Eldridge, move down that wall and maintain a visual. Move. Move.
Eldridge teetering down the wall.
Roger, roger. I'm on him. He's still walking.
SOUND of BREATHING in Sanborn's walkie.
James, the smoke is killing my visibility. Where are you in relation to the IED? Are you 100 meters, yet?     JAMES
Hell, I don't know. I'll let you know when I'm standing over it.
We see the world from James' point of view now, the city Baghdad has taken on an intense and dreamy hue, as if we' in some sort of fugue state:
--He looks down the strange, threatening Iraqi street.
He walks on. The suit is heavy, little puffs of sand with each footfall. The sun beats down.
James nears an intersection guarded on either side by a Humvee and several SOLDIERS, when...   INTERSECTION

Suddenly a red-and-white TAXI swerves past the SOLDIERS o the left side of the intersection. The soldiers take cove and shout contradictory commands - Get Down Motherfucker! Don't Move! Back up! Out of the vehicle!
The TAXI BRAKES in front of James.   UPRANGE
Sanborn and Eldridge can hear the shouting but the linger smoke still obscures their sight.
(shouting to Sanborn) Car! Car! A car stopped in front of him.   JAMES
James' HEADSET WALKIE barks to life:
Come back.
James pulls a pistol from his holster, and --
I got it.
-- shoots two rounds into the dirt, near the car's front tire.  DRIVER'S FACE
Impossible to read. Is he a taxi driver annoyed by the roadblock, or an insurgent fighter getting ready to blow suicide bomb?
With field glasses on the intersection he speaks into the walkie.
EOD has a nine on this Haji in the car. I'm going to get two guys over there to back him up.   SANBORN
Still can't see clearly. Processing this information.   T to Eldridge.
Eldridge using his rifle scope as well - shakes his head. visual.
(into walkie to soldier) Negative, negative. You're too close to the IED--
Stand down. EOD has the situation under control.
Sweat on his forehead.  JAMES
Now aiming at the windshield. But the driver is impassive     UPRANGE
Eldridge looks through his rifle scope.
(shouting to Sanborn) We're in a kill zone!   INTERSECTION
James fires, shattering the windshield. But the car doesn budge.
James is pissed. He lunges through the windshield and jam his gun into the driver's forehead.  SOLDIER
Three or four rounds fired. The nine is now pressing into the Haji's forehead.  INTERSECTION
The gun digs into the driver's forehead. Beat. The driver shifts into reverse.
He rolls back to the soldiers, who then rush the car, yan the driver out, and deliver a savage beating as James loo on.   JAMES
(chuckling into his
If he wasn't an insurgent he sure as hell is now.
And he resumes his walk towards the white garbage bag and rubble pile, noting possible threats -- a MAN in a window down the road.  UPRANGE
(coolly, into walkie) Copy that.
But I have no idea what you're talking about, Blaster One, since I can't see you. Over.
I'll tell you later. James out.
One of a million in this city. James draws near. Two wire protrude from the mess.

Moving quickly, he deftly removes rubble and trash to exp the wires and the artillery shells they are attached to - sees out of his peripheral vision the MAN in the window - reaches for his pistol -- but the man disappears from vie he then goes back to work, with swift sure hands. He love this, loves being close to oblivion.
The wires are exposed. He cuts one. Then flips the artill rounds over and cuts the other wire.
We're done.
He stands and uses his big boot to clear more rubble. A banana peel is pushed away, revealing:
Another wire snaking out of the ground.
Secondary!
James spins to look uprange. Sees Sanborn motioning for t men to get down.  UPRANGE
Off the wall, Owen!
Get behind something. Find cover.
Soldiers scrambling to find concrete to hide behind.  JAMES
James YANKS the wire out of the dirt but it turns out to buried like a root, and the more he rips the more the wir revealed. He rips and rips, going back ten feet.
---The wire is stuck in the ground, and it will not come anymore. James digs with a knife -- FURIOUSLY moving eart until he reaches a third artillery shell, which he pulls of the ground.
--CU knife blade inside the shell --
--CU James' helmet - glass clouding over from condensatio losing visibility.
--ECU blasting cap --
--ECU knife tip separates the wire...
James strides uprange. Eldridge isn't sure what to make o James. Sanborn is, but not ready to show it.
(gulping air as the helmet
Did you see that guy? (smiles, recovers his
Man, I need a beer.
Sanborn begins the bomb suit removal ritual - unstrapping Velcro.
We can arrange that.
He yanks at the strap - a little roughly.
What do you like?
Colt.
Nice southern brand.
Yanks at another strap.
James looks down, the tone of Sanborn's voice and the for of the strap gets his attention.
Eldridge picks up the pieces of the suit and places them the Humvee. Listening to this exchange.
I'd take a beer.
Hey, that wasn't too bad, for our first time working together.
I think working together is I talk to you. And you talk to me.
Are we going on a date, J.T.?
Sanborn stands, removing the last piece of the suit.
No, we're going on a mission. And it's my job to keep you safe, so we can keep going on missions.
Hey, this is combat.
With that James walks to the Humvee and gets inside.
Sanborn closes the trunk, hard, startling Eldridge.    El comes close, speaking out of James' earshot.
It's just thirty nine days.
Thirty eight. Assuming we survive today.
Tick-tock. Tick-tock.   INT HUMVEE
James is in the passenger seat, waiting impatiently. Sanb and Eldridge get in.
I don't mean to mix it up. But the situation dictated it.
Roger that.
I'm serious. We're gonna work together. You'll get used to my ops tempo.
Your ops tempo?
I don't always stop to chat, and I like to go fast. You know, so the insurgents don't have time to plan. I don't want them make any cell phone calls.
Off Sanborn's face.

head_text.subj: INT. CAMP VICTORY MESS TENT DAY

text: Eldridge and Sanborn chowing down - two guys among a sea SOLDIERS. Behind them in the mess tent hang the signs of various fast-food restaurants that cater to the troops: P HUT, SUBWAY, BURGER KING.
Ketchup?
Eldridge passes his ketchup over to Sanborn.
This is not Pizza Hut. (removing a slice of
And this is not pepperoni. It's round and meaty, but it ain't pepperoni.
Goat meat, probably.
Goat meat pepperoni? I'd be glad if this was goat meat pepperoni.
I'd eat a truckload of goat meat pepperoni. No, this is something else. (slapping the fake pepperoni on the table) This is unholy.
Pray for something better -- and while you're at it, pray for a new team leader.
You sure you want to be the guy in the bomb suit?
They see James at a food station.
Be better than him.
James approaches the table.
Hey, James.
James sits down to an awkward silence. Eldridge stops eat Considers him.
That was some crazy shit you pulled out there.
Yeah?

Hell yeah. You're either really lucky or really good. Right up on the car like that. Gun to the head. Crazy. You know it might backfire on you someday. You know that. You might actually die. And then what?
James is puzzled.
I don't know, what?
You don't meet your maker. You just get vaporized into little bits of DNA.
Sanborn watches Eldridge closely. Is he referring to Thompson?
(trying to be helpful) He asks everyone what they think about death. Ever since Thompson was KIA.
James nods, turns to Eldridge:
I don't think about it. Waste of time.
James goes back to eating.     Eldridge keeps looking at then lets it go.

head_text.subj: EXT. CAMP VICTORY MESS TENT DAY

text: Midday in Iraq. The heat is oppressive, biblical.
James, Sanborn and Eldridge emerge into the blazing sun a the tumult of the base. Trucks barrel by. And troops -- everywhere, troops.
James stops in front of young Iraqi KID selling pirated D while Sanborn and Eldridge continue on to the head shed. kid, whose name is PELE, has DVDs fanned on a table.
One for five, two for nine.
Three for twelve?
Three for thirteen. And for you, no tax.
(laughing, fishes out a five) Keep the change.
Sanborn is smoking a cigarette and watching James buy DVD weighing him, when the team's FIRST SERGEANT, stocky with paternal way about him, holds out a white envelope to Sanborn.
The tags finally came. Figured you'd want to be the one to take them over.(handing Sanborn the
Thanks, I will handle it.
The Sergeant nods. Sanborn stuffs the envelope in his bac pocket. And the Sergeant heads inside, walking past --

A small office space with the door opened a crack. Behind door, Eldridge is sitting on a swivel chair, looking at a computer screen, playing a computer game. Next to him in another swivel chair is LT. COL. JOHN CAMBRIDGE, a MILITA PSYCHIATRIST, who is looking at Eldridge and the screen.
(singing the jingle) "Be all that you can be," right? But what if all I can be is dead on the side of an Iraqi road?
I'd like to see you move past this feeling that you're going to die, Owen.
(looking at the screen) Why? I think it's logical. This is a war, right Doc? People die all the time. Why not me?
That's true. But what concerns me is how much you think about it. You have to change the record in your head, think about other things.
What do you think about?
I don't dwell on death.(looking at his watch) I don't obsess. You understand what I'm getting at?
Eldridge looks up at last.

head_text.subj: EXT CAMP VICTORY JAMES' TRAILER NIGHT

text: James stands before the open door of his trailer with the satellite phone in hand. Overhead a canopy of stars blink
Through the earpiece of the phone the faint but unmistaka BEEP of an answering machine.

Hey, guess you're out...wherever you are you're probably wearing those tight jeans, damn those look good... Anyway, Baghdad's alright, guys are a little uptight down here, but then they just lost a brother so I understand... uh...(looking up at the stars)...really beautiful night, wish you could see these stars...miss you...bye...
He disconnects.    Sits in the darkness.   Distant WASH o engine noise.

head_text.subj: INT CAMP VICTORY SHOWER STALLS NEXT MORNING

text: Sanborn is shaving in a mirror, otherwise dressed for com and ready to go, when James shuffles in wearing a T-shirt boxer shorts, looking like he just woke up.
Sanborn can't believe James is this relaxed.
Hey.
Hey.
James starts to brush his teeth.
I gotta talk to you about something before we roll out.
James keeps brushing.
Shoot.
Yesterday -- that was not cool.
I know. We'll get it.
More tooth brushing. Face cleaning.
James notices a tatoo on Sanborn's forearm.
I was in Military Intel for seven years. Before EOD. We ran combat missions in every shit hole on the
(beat, smile on his face) So I'm pretty sure I can figure out a dumb trailer park redneck like you.
(spitting out water,
Looks like you're on the right track.

head_text.subj: INT HUMVEE SOMEWHERE IN BAGHDAD MORNING

text: Sanborn drives. James in the passenger seat. Eldridge is the gunner's turret. They ride in silence, each man alone with his thoughts.   TITLE OVER:

head_text.subj: DAYS LEFT IN BRAVO COMPANY'S ROTATION
EXT ROAD BEHIND BRITISH EMBASSY DAY

text: A faded blue Opal sits by a high wall laced with concerti wire. It's at the end of a narrow cul de sac which backs the embassy.
The narrow cul de sac dog-legs into another street. At th entrance to the cul de sac, there is a phalanx of SOLDIER and our EOD techs.
Sanborn and Eldridge are unloading the robot from the Hum
Other soldiers are evacuating OFFICE WORKERS from the embassy.
James seems frustrated with the situation - frowning into face of the SERGEANT in charge.

An office worker called it in. The car doesn't belong to anyone who works at the building. It's been parked there for an hour. No license plate and the suspension is sagging, so there's something heavy in the trunk -- three or four hundred pounds. Could be a bomb.
Did you evacuate?
We're trying. But the English Ambassador said we're supposed to guarantee his safety.
Sanborn approaches, lap top in hand.
Bot is ready.
A WOMAN in a Bhurka on a motorcycle rides past the Soldie and towards the Opal --
(raising his rifle) Shit -- What do you want me to do?
Shoot her.
We can't shoot her for riding a bike...
-- CU the motorcyclist's hands, holding a MOLOTOV COCKTAI It's hidden from view of the soldiers.
-- She rolls the cocktail under the car and darts down an ALLEY
The car BURSTS into flames, and the scene breaks into --  PANDEMONIUM --
-- Eldridge frantically straps James into the suit, as th car burns.
-- James takes off his sunglasses, cleans them, calmly.
-- Sanborn runs to the truck and returns with a fire extinguisher, which he hands to James.
Eldridge - I want you in that window - keep the alley clear. Sanborn, cover it from the street.
Sanborn looks at the alley: not a happy place. Eldridge t off towards the Embassy entrance.

AMBASSADOR SIR AUCKLAND GEDDES, the epitome of the old st of British foreign service: elegant, self assured, a gentleman adventurer in Seville Row, hoping to improve th world, certain he'll profit in the attempt.

He's holding court with a group of EXECUTIVES. The execut are seated around a conference table under the Ambassador sway. There's a model of a British Petroleum gas station/convenience store, in English and Arabic, in the center of the table.
...So in sixteen months time I believe five million gallons per day is in fact rather conservative.
SOUNDS out the window. An Executive turns his head nervou
But security is still the big variable?
The Ambassador brushes his hand in dismissal.
Only on the margins.
Everyday, the risks diminish and the rewards multiply--
Eldridge enters.
Ah, and here is EOD. You see gentlemen, everything is fine. The site is secure. The bomb -- if there even is one -- will easily be dispensed by the crack American team.
Excuse me.
Eldridge rushes over to the window to see the street.
Blaster Mike, I'm at the window.   SANBORN
He's stationed himself near the mouth of the alley.   Wis smoke and flames in the air.
Copy that. How's the fire look from up there.   AMBASSADOR'S OFFICE
Flames a meter high, over.   JAMES
Close to the burning car. SMOKE rising from the hood and under carriage awash in FLAMES, like a sleeping dragon.

James sprays the fire-extinguisher and the fire subsides. inspects the interior - looks normal enough - and tries t open the trunk with a pair of pliers, but the handle does give and snaps off under his effort. He kicks the trunk b it remains shut. He turns and lumbers up range, jaw set.   SANBORN
Watching James walk back uprange.
Blaster One, what is going on?
Stay put, I'll be right back.
Standing alone in the kill zone at the mouth of the alley
What's happening?
Good question. But I'm not liking it.   HUMVEE

James is buried inside the Humvee, searching. He tosses w he doesn't need, and a succession of items comes flying o food, clothing, a tarp. Now James walks back towards the Opal without saying a word. In his hand is a crowbar.   BLUE OPAL
James winds up and swings hard at the door. Wham! Nope. W Wham! Wham!
He drops the crowbar and tries the trunk. Presto, it open revealing: a trunk overflowing with EXPLOSIVES -- ten tim what we've seen before. James is taken aback.
We're all in the kill zone on this one.   SANBORN
Sanborn stares at James and the car. Great.     JAMES

Now inside the car, slipping on the slimy seats, he cuts seat cushions with his knife, and rips out the foam upholstery, and finds more bad news buried underneath: SI ARTILLERY SHELLS and a WIRE that leads to the floorboard goes under the carpeting.

James DIVES to the wire and cuts it, then rips open the carpet to reveal more wire -- and follows the wire throug the car, ripping apart the car PIECE by PIECE, cutting wi as he goes.   AMBASSADOR'S OFFICE
An executive gets up to look out the window.
Sir, I'm going to need you to stay away from the window.
Yes, please, sit down. It's safe.
Why is he here, if it's safe?
He is just an observer.
Is that true, we're safe here?
In my opinion, no.
Executives take this as a cue to leave. Getting up, shuff out of the room. The Ambassador is furious at Eldridge, advancing on him.
This is idiotic. Why not tow the vehicle away from the building?
I believe the lane is too narrow for a Humvee, Sir.
Donkeys.   Use donkeys.
I don't believe we have any of those on hand, Sir.
Jesus, Lord. You Americans really are incompetent. No donkeys on hand? What do you think I'm talking about, a full squadron of farm animals?
Eldridge trying to stay on task.
(cutting him off) Go downstairs, grab a farmer or one of those street vendors and procure - meaning purchase, buy - several donkeys. Then tow this car bomb away from my office.
Sir, I'm going to need you to step away from the window.
Geddes looks out the window at the burning car.   SANBORN
His walkie barks to life.
(over Sanborn's walkie) Lot of pink Det cord here.
Where's the switch?   JAMES
Not in the back seat.
James is now in the front seat, tearing up the upholstery
Not in the front seat. Doors. Dash.
A WISP of smoke curls out of the heating vents. James doe notice.
If you haven't found it yet, it's probably under the car.
None of the cord goes under. It's up here -- somewhere.
Try the weather-stripping.
James rips off a chunk of weather stripping. Just bare me   SANBORN
It's been thirty seconds. You need to bail.
I can find it.   JAMES
He crawls to the back seat, slipping on the foam and slim More smoke escapes from the vents.
James, seriously, you need to bail.
Roger that. Be right out.
James retraces what's left of the wire, yet again, ignori Sanborn. He sits back in the seat, strangely relaxed.
A shadow comes into Sanborn's sight. It's an IRAQI on a bicycle, riding straight towards him.
Incoming.
Sanborn raises his rifle. The man peddles on, waving his hand.
Where is the entrance to this building?
Imshee! Imshee!
The bicyclist looks at the car.   ELDRIDGE
Trains his scope on the head of the bicyclist.
I'm going to burn him on three. One.
Geddes just looks at the big man at the window.
Oh, that's rich. Give him a count.
Through Eldridge's scope the bicyclist grows.     He flic his safety.
Blaster Mike, do you copy?
Please don't make me kill you.
Been in combat very long?     SANBORN
(into walkie to Eldridge) Copy that.
James, you need to get out. There's another potential bomber here.
So shoot him.
I need to make a delivery down there. Please let me through.   AMBASSADOR'S OFFICE
Two!!   SANBORN
Negative, Negative. Hold your fire. (shouting at bicyclist) Get the fuck out of here!
The bicyclist does an about face, but not before casting last suspicious glance back at the car bomb.
Sanborn refocuses on the Opal; he's losing his cool.
Blaster One, do you copy, over?     JAMES
Still sitting in the back seat. Now he sees the smoking v
Gimmie a minute.   ELDRIDGE
Eyes never leaving the street below, flicks the safety of rifle back on.
Geddes notices the sweat on Eldridge's face, and feels a sudden surge of sympathy for the younger man.
Well done.     That took great self control.
Thank you, sir. Again, I apologize for the intrusion into --
Yes, but I doubt the insurgents will appreciate your restraint. (in a kindly, paternal tone) If I may give you a piece of free advice, next time, pull the trigger.
Well, actually, the uh--rules --

That's the only way out, I'm afraid. When you're in a losing battle, you have to draw blood. No insurgency in modern history has ever been truly defeated, so all you can do is manage your exit. Clear a wide swath of bodies so you have room to withdraw.
Suddenly the office door opens and a YOUNG AIDE appears.
The building is empty, Sir, except for you.
Geddes nods, grabs his coat and moves to Eldridge for one last jab.

I'm sorry to say it, but that's just how it's done. You need to show some vigor. In Kenya, we executed the insurgents in their beds, until they gave us room. Falklands, the same. That's just how it's done.
Eldridge looks up, he's had enough.   Swings around.
Is that how you did it in Northern Ireland? With murder?
There you are. Now you're showing some vigor.
And leaves.
J.T, the building is clear now. We can pull out.   SANBORN
Roger that. (to James) Will, we can pull out. The building is evacuated.
James?
Still no answer.
Blaster One, we are cleared to leave this fucking site. Walk away. Do you copy, over?     JAMES
Stay where you are, Sanborn. I'm not done.
And with that, James turns off his walkie.      CLICK.   ELDRIDGE
J.T., are we moving?   SANBORN
Negative. Negative.
I didn't copy that. Did you say negative?
Roger. We are staying until James is finished.
James, what's the situation?
Goddamn, Will, I need a report.   JAMES
James' POV. He sees in the corner of the back seat, havin just wiped away a puddle of fire retardant, a little blac box, with a wire leading out of it. He grabs the box.
Got it.   BLUE OPAL
The black box goes flying out of the car.

head_text.subj: EXT MOUTH OF CUL DE SAC

text: Sanborn is furious, stalking ahead of James as they retur uprange.
Sanborn passes Eldridge, who has come down from the ambassador's office.
Take the suit.   HUMVEE
James' face looks flushed, red, sweat dripping. Eldridge begins ripping apart the Velcro from James' legs.   MOMENTS LATER
James sits in the car, smoking.
Sanborn leans into the window.
Hey, James.
Yeah?
Sanborn JABS him in the jaw, knocking the cigarette out.
Don't you turn off your walkie again.
Sanborn stalks off and James explodes out of the car.

He crouches down -- searching the floor of the Humvee. Se his cigarette, damaged and dirty on the mucky floor, but still burning. He extracts it and carefully cleans it off then jumps on the hood of the Humvee and goes back to his smoke. He's calm as can be. The Marlboro man.
As he puffs away, watching Sanborn converse with a group SOLDIERS, a JEEP drives up.
COLONEL REED jumps out wearing a uniform covered in army bling - medals he won a long time ago, before he traveled the food chain. An AIDE trots along beside him.
Hi boys.
James turns around.
Hello, sir.
(points to James) That you in the bomb suit?
Yes, sir, it was.
(reading his name tag) You were the guy in the flaming car, Sergeant James?
James is concerned.
Yes, sir.
Well hot damn, that was some hot shit. You're a wild man, you know that?
The Colonel spins his head around to Eldridge.
He's a wild man, you know that? (back to James) Let me shake your hand.
Extending his meaty paw.
Thank you, sir.
Slapping him on the back.
How many bombs have you disarmed, Sergeant?
James seems slightly self-conscious.   Eldridge listens i
Hell, I'm not sure.    A lot.
Sergeant, I asked you a question.
One seven three.   Counting today, Sir.
Holy shit. One hundred and seventy fucking three bombs. God damn. That must be a record. So tell me, what's the best way to go about disarming one of these things?
James doesn't answer as he looks at the black box. Finall
The way you don't die.
Good one, spoken like a wild man.
I'd like a picture with this man - anybody here have a camera?
A nearby soldier holds a digital camera up to his eye. Colonel Reed smiles big, arm draped around James's should SNAP.
Thanks, sir, thank you very much. Sir, couldn't do it without my team (looking around for Sanborn) Hey, Sanborn! Get over here!
Sanborn trots over, glowering.
(to Col. Reed) This here is Sergeant Sanborn, the key to the whole team. (rubbing it in) And Specialist Eldridge.
Colonel Reed extends his hand. Sanborn is shocked.
You guys should all get Bronze stars and I'm gonna recommend it.
Thank you, Sir.                 Thank you, Sir.
Thanks, Sir.
Good luck, boys. Keep on keeping on.
Out of earshot Colonel Reed addresses his aide.
You wouldn't catch me walking down on no fuckin' bomb. Hell no, you're not gonna get me in that monkey suit.   HUMVEE
James sits in the front with his IPOD earphones on.   Los the world.
Eldridge starts to climb into the turret.    Before he do speaks softly to Sanborn.
Bronze star?
I don't care, (not caring that James may overhear) the guy is not safe. You can have mine and I'll pin it on your coffin.
So you do think I'm going to die.
Fuck, Owen. I don't know. Probably not.

head_text.subj: EXT CAMP VICTORY WEAPONS DISCHARGE STATION AFTERNOON

text: James, Sanborn and Eldridge are discharging their weapons dry firing them into steel drums. Clicking of ammunition. Long shadows.

head_text.subj: EXT CAMP VICTORY FIRST SERGEANT'S TRAILER AFTERNOON

text: James steps out, grabs a smoke, as a soccer ball rolls be him. It's Pele's. Inviting James to play.
Ball! Ball!
James picks it up, and carries it over to a pile of sandb and sits down. Pele runs up.
Give it.
Give me my five bucks and I'll give you your ball.
Five dollars - for what?
Those DVDs were crap. They were so fuzzy I couldn't see a thing.
No, impossible.
I'm telling you, they were fuzzy.
That's Hollywood, my man. Special effects.
The boy's chutzpa amuses James. He's starting to like thi kid.
What's your name anyway?
Pele.
Oh yeah - like the soccer player?
Yes, the great Pele
James gets up. Motions for the kid to give him space.
Ready? One, two --
He smashes the ball in Pele's direction -- it flies up. P blocks it easily, kicking high in the air.
-- three. Shit.
Pele comes back over to James, who has sat back down.   H notices the bomb patch on James' uniform.
(pointing to the patch) So you are EOD -- boomala boomala. It's fun, no?
I like to disarm them. Tell   you what, kid, I'll buy another   DVD from you but if this one is   fuzzy you better watch out. Cause   I'm coming for you.

head_text.subj: INT CAMP VICTORY MESS TENT DAY

text: Sanborn and Eldridge eat together. In the corner of the r James is eating alone in a sea of soldiers.
Eldridge and the psychiatrist are back in session.
What if I should be pulling the trigger more often? Killing people? Bomb makers.
That's not your mission. Your mission is to protect life. Render safe.

But what if I need to change the mission - to survive? That bicyclist I told you about? I'm ninety percent sure he was an insurgent. I could have shot him. Not my mission. But it would have been legal.
You don't have to turn into an animal just to protect yourself.
You don't?
No.
And you know this from your extensive work in the field.
I've done my field duty.
Where was that? Yale?

Look, Specialist, if you want to stop talking to me, you can. These sessions are voluntary. You chose to be here, talking to me, just like you chose the Army, just like you chose EOD. You're in an elite volunteer unit. Not many guys have the IQ or the nerves to do it. Be proud of it.
Eldridge considers this.    The psychiatrist taps his pen Waiting.
Keep the soldier in the fight and the fight in the soldier, right Doc?
Eldridge puts out his hand, and they shake.
Seriously, I appreciate what you're saying. But you need to get out from behind this desk more.

head_text.subj: INT CAMP VICTORY LAUNDRY ROOM NIGHT

text: James is watching his clothes dry as they tumble around t machine.
Sanborn comes in with a pile of laundry. Sees James.
Hey.
Hey.
Sanborn stuffs his laundry into a machine. James is still watching the drier, starts to speak.

If you ever get in my shoes and put on the bomb suit you'll see your whole mind changes when you're in front of a bomb. You lose 20 IQ points just from the weight of the suit. Your brain gets so much adrenaline that you hallucinate. Turn off the walkie?
Sanborn stares straight ahead.
You'll be lucky if all you do is turn off the walkie.
Off the spinning dryer, we --

head_text.subj: EXT BAGHDAD SOMEWHERE IN THE CITY MID AFTERNOON

text: Heat playing tricks with light on the ribbon of road - imaginary water pooling on the surface.
Again, the auditory landscape of Baghdad: distant CALL to prayer and the incessant RAT-TAT-TAT of gunfire.     TITLE OVER:

head_text.subj: DAYS LEFT IN BRAVO COMPANY'S ROTATION

text: James is walking uprange with a large artillery shell. It looks very heavy and he's sweating profusely.
He brings the bomb to the Humvee where Sanborn and Eldrid are waiting. They're also suffering in the heat. They tak the shell from him, and stow it in the truck.
How are we on water? I'm dying.
J.T.'s got some.
Water?
No. I'm all out.
James just looks at him.
We're at the south end of an EXPLOSIVES DISPOSAL RANGE, nicknamed, `Purgatory' -- an empty expanse of dirt pockma with craters and bordered on one side by a small number o dwellings.
BOOM!!! A huge bomb explodes, sending dust and debris int the air in a mini mushroom cloud...We move across the fie with the cloud, and settle where our EOD team is position by their Humvee.
Sanborn has a remote detonator in his hand and is about t blow it.
Fire in the hole. Fire in the hole
James interrupts --
Hold on a second. I think I forgot my gloves back there.
James jumps into the Humvee and drives down range, revers the course we just took. It's a long way to the explosive at least half a mile, and Sanborn and Eldridge watch him recede in the distance.
James is a tiny figure, ambling around the explosives pil There's nobody else around.
Sanborn looks down at the detonator in his hand. Eldridge notices the look.
Those detonators break all the time. Accidental misfire.
With that shot laid out like that, it could be a UXO that just cooks off.
Boom.
Boom.
A shot that size would obliterate everything in its path.
His helmet, you'd have that.
Oh yeah, there'd be half a helmet somewhere.
And little bits of hair stuck to it.
Little bits of hair.
We'd have to recommend a major change in techniques and protocols so that kind of accident never happens again. You'd write the first draft of the report.
Are you serious?
I'm not going to write it.
No, are you serious about killing him?
-- Sanborn looks up at Eldridge. Smiles.
James starts driving back uprange.

head_text.subj: EXT FIELD OUTSKIRTS OF BAGHDAD LATE AFTERNOON

text: Another dusty nowhere. The EOD team is stopped in the mid of a road that cuts through a swath of desert.
At the roadside are several SOLDIERS and their vehicles. soldiers look sunburned, tired.
Sanborn and Eldridge are near the soldiers, looking down road where --   TITLE OVER:

head_text.subj: DAYS LEFT IN BRAVO COMPANY'S ROTATION

text: CRATER

James is inside a CRATER in the middle of the road, worki on an EIGHT-FOOT MISSILE. He attaches A ROCKET WRENCH, a metal band with two explosive tubes, to the nose of the missile -- and flips a switch.

The two   tubes ignite like a firecracker, shooting small flames.   Then the flames grow and band spins and FLIES o ZIPPING   into the air above James' head like a metal fri landing   fifty feet away.
James peers into the nose cone.    A hollow void.
James? Do you copy? James?
He climbs to the top of the crater.
It's empty.
The soldiers are gathered around the pit to see EOD work. It's not everyday you get to see an eight foot missile to out of a hole.

James is down in the pit. Sanborn hands him a chain. Work together, they wrap it around the missile. When they're d Sanborn signals Eldridge, who is behind the wheel of the Humvee, ready to tow the missile out of the crater.
Rock it out, slowly.
The chain creaks, then stops. The tires spin uselessly.
Try gunning it.
The tires only spin faster.
Sanborn moves to get a closer look. His knees come very n to the creaking chain.
(seeing this from the pit) Sanborn, watch that chain.
It's alright.
When...

KA-BOOOOM -- the sky flashes orange overhead --James flat his back, dazed. A shard of metal ZOOMS into the pit, mis him by inches -- as the soldiers dive into the pit for co shouting "RPG, RPG!"   HUMVEE
Eldridge, who is in the driver's seat, starts shooting hi rifle.
What am I shooting at?
Sanborn jumping into the Humvee.
I don't fucking know! -- but James is down!!!
He fires in the same direction as Eldridge. The Humvee ge peppered with bullets. The armor holds. But it doesn't lo like it's going to last for much longer.
Sanborn grabs Eldridge. And they dive back into the pit, joining James and THREE SOLDIERS: a SERGEANT one PRIVATE a CORPORAL who is a SNIPER.
James is sitting up, taking off his bomb suit. He appears be unharmed.   ROAD
One of the soldiers is in the turret of a Humvee, firing big .50 machine gun in all directions.   CRATER
Get up there with your Barret and help him out.
[Note: Barret is the large .50 SNIPER RIFLE carried by on the soldiers, a specialty gun with an extremely long rang
The SNIPER hoists the heavy gun to the edge of the crater looks down the scope.
As he does, Sanborn, Eldridge, and James, and the other soldiers pop up and lay down covering fire. Then they qui pop back down.   ROAD
The soldier in the Humvee is still churning his machine g shooting in all directions, expending hundreds of bullets minute.     CRATER
I don't see nothing out there. Chris is shooting wild.
Hey Chris - can you hear me? Chill out on the fifty man.   ROAD
The soldier in the Humvee fires a few more seconds. Picks his walkie.
Copy that.
-- As a bullet hits him in the neck, killing him instantl   CRATER
Holy shit. He killed Chris.
Everyone in the pit pops up and fires in every direction, knee-jerk response.
A soldier picks up his walkie and keys it. We can't hear talking over the retorts of the soldiers firing rifles.
The men are pinned down, paralyzed by fear. Sniper fire f one of the buildings rakes the top of the crater.
-- Bullets kick up sand on the far side of the crater, opposite the men.
-- Eldridge looks like he's having a heart attack. This i how it ends, he thinks.
--James seems preternaturally calm.
After a while --
We should save our ammo at least until we can see these bastards.
The Sergeant takes off his pack, and pulls out a pair of binoculars. Inching up to the edge of the crater, where h joins the SNIPER
Do you see anything.
It's got to be coming from those buildings. Somebody moved on the roof of the tall one there.
We see the buildings in the distance. They look too far a to be threatening.
Hit him if you see him again.
As suddenly --
The SNIPER is hit in the breastbone.
Oh fuck. Oh fuck. Jesus.
In the pit: total meltdown. This is it. The day you die. Everyone starts talking at once.
Man we got to get out of         I'll get on the Barret. here.
Don't do that J.T.               Shit. Okay. We need help
Roger that, Alpha Nine. Go          (to Sergeant) ahead.                           Let me see those binocs.
The Sergeant hands the binocs to James.
We are taking incoming fire. I have two KIA. The grid --
James gives Sanborn a look. He leans in to say something Sanborn, which we can't hear.
Over the Sergeant's walkie:
I know where you are Alpha. Go ahead.
Sanborn crawls into the SNIPER's position, moving the dea body out of the way. James follows next to him to observe with the binocs
Copy that. Okay. Can you get us some help. (to James and Sanborn) Don't do that fellas.
Sanborn is already shooting. The SNIPER RIFLE puts down bullets slowly. It has a clip of six rounds. One by one Sanborn expends them.
Eldridge, I need ammo.
Eldridge pulls two clips of ammunition off the bloody che of the dead sniper.
(looking through the
You're shooting high.
Eldridge hands the ammo to Sanborn, who jams the clip in rifle, and then adjusts the sight. He pulls the trigger. gun jams.
Clear it, clear it. (the clip is removed, passed to James) Eldridge clean the bullets. The blood is making them jam.

Eldridge is handed the bloody clips. He pops the bullets one by one, and tries to clean them. But the blood is sti A bullet slips out of his hand, rolls down the crater. Th soldier helps him by picking up the bullet and cleaning i
James looks back to see Eldridge's progress.
Spit on `em Eldridge. Spit. Rub. Spit rub.
Eldridge is trying. He's really trying.
Come on, Eldridge. I need ammo.
James sees that Eldridge is not getting it and he draws c to him.
You're doing good, man. (putting his hand on Eldridge's shoulder). You're okay.
Eldridge nods. His mind is there but his hands are disobe him. James attempts to clear his head.
I will keep you safe, Owen, that's my job.
Roger.
The soldier hands the ammo to James.
(to both of them) Alright. Scan your sectors.
Then Eldridge positions himself so he's looking in the opposite direction that James and Sanborn are looking.
Sanborn fires two more rounds.
Still high, adjust your windage. Elevation.
Got it.
The roof of the tall building in the distance bobs in and of view. At this great range, the scope dances.     CRATER
He's on the left by the smoke stack. Guy in white.
Sanborn fires once. He turns his head away from the gun a makes an audible exhale to release tension -- the sniper breath control technique.
Good. There's another one just behind him. Up a meter.
Sanborn fires once. Audible exhale.
Good.
James scans the area. Silence.
The sun lower in the sky. Around the pit, the fallen sold has been pushed to one side, and the living are hanging o their sanity.
Eldridge and the remaining soldier have exhausted their w supply.

Sanborn and James are in EXACTLY the same position as whe left them. Focused. Sanborn's finger on the trigger. Sanb breathes out, the sniper breathing. He's been doing this an hour, time and the desert heat have taken their toll.
Sanborn blinks sweat away.   SANBORN POV
The scope BLURS. He regains focus.   JAMES
Noticing Sanborn's fatigue.
Eldridge, grab me the juice out of an MRE.
Eldridge digs around the DEAD SOLDIER'S backpack and retrieves a packet of juice, which he passes to James.
James inserts the straw into the juice pack.
He hesitates, not sure if Sanborn will accept the gesture after all the hostility that's passed between them. But h brings the straw to Sanborn's lips.
At first, Sanborn keeps his attention on the rifle scope. then he opens his parched mouth, and sips.
--Suddenly, there's movement, a flutter of fabric, in the distance off Eldridge's shoulder. He stiffens.
Uh, Will.
Yeah.
At my one o'clock. Two hundred meters. Something moved behind a parked car. Either a tan dog or a man in a light-colored shirt.
Deal with it.
Uh--Ok.
Eldridge looks down his scope, unsure. James keeps his fo forward on the building.
I don't think it's a dog.   Should I fire?
It's your call.
Eldridge shifts his weight onto his rifle.
There's a flutter of movement in the distance.
Eldridge pulls the trigger. Spraying the car in the dista Empties his entire magazine.
From behind the car, something falls to the ground, and t tiniest sliver of a rifle clatters after it.
The soldier in the pit comes over to Eldridge to see what he's done.
Good hit, man.
James and Sanborn don't turn around.
Eldridge slumps, spent.
Sun casting long shadows.
James and Sanborn in the same focused position. Eldridge still watches the rear.
The soldier in the pit reaches his breaking point.
I'm going to go for the Humvee. What do you say?
I don't know.
We've been here two hours and they ain't seen nothing. I'm going to go for it.
And with that he dashes up and out of the crater.
Sanborn keeps his eye on the scope.  ROAD
The soldier runs to the Humvee, gets in, and turns the vehicle around, driving it back to the pit.
He dives out of the vehicle and back to the pit.
Those fuckers are dead.
What if they hit us with an RPG when we get out? What if they were just waiting for us to get in the Humvee.
It's safe. I'm telling you
You got those fuckers.
The soldier jumps out of the pit. Stands in the middle of road. A sitting duck.
(to men in the pit) See? You got them. (turning to building,
We got you mother fuckers. You're fucking dead Hajis. Haha.
The soldier pulls down his pants and moons the building.
Kiss this mother fucker!!!
James lowers his binocs. Sanborn lowers his rifle.
They exchange a mirthful look.

head_text.subj: INT CAMP VICTORY JAMES' TRAILER NIGHT

text: James and Sanborn face each other; both men are red-faced drunk, swaying.
Ready?
Sanborn nods. Wham! Sanborn reels back from the punch. Ja is standing over him. Glowering. He looks good. The rage like a vitamin.
Now we're even.
Sanborn stumbles back, recovers. Around them in James' ro are the remains of an Irish wake: two bottles of Scotch, already empty. A third half gone. Cigarettes burned down an ashtray.
Be right back. I gotta piss.
As Sanborn stumbles out, James turns to Eldridge
One more, boy.
(imitating a young
Yes, Sir, Sergeant James Sir. You're not very good drunk are you SIR!! You're a good fighter, Sir. Natural born warrior, Sir.
You acquitted yourself well on the field of battle today.
Really? I got scared.
Everyone is a coward at some point in their lives.
Sanborn comes in. He sees a box under James' bed. Sanborn picks up the box under James' bed and plops it on the tab intentionally breaking up the love-fest between James and Eldridge.
Hey Owen, look! Will has possessions! I didn't know you owned anything, Will.
Sanborn pulls a picture frame out of the box. It's a pict of a baby boy. Eldridge leans in.
That's my son. A real tough little bastard. Like me.
So you're married?
James is uncomfortable with the subject. Intimacy isn't e for him. He rolls his eyes, nods.
Well, she was my girlfriend, we had a baby, then she became my wife, then we got divorced. (pause) I thought we got divorced. (pause) But she's still in the house, and she says we're still together.
So, I don't know. What does that make her?
Dumb, to be with you?
She ain't dumb. She's loyal.
My problem is the one girl who I like keeps talking about kids. Kids. Kids.
Give her your sperm, stud.
Nah. I'm not ready. (looking around the box, finds a circuit board.) ) And what's this?
Sanborn sees there are many such parts in the box.
Bomb parts.
No shit. Why do you have them?
James reaches into the box. Pulls out a circuit. Looks at admiringly.
This is from the Blue Opal. (to himself) It's wild, isn't it, to hold something in your hands that could have killed you. (he tosses the board to Sanborn)
Eldridge leans over, pulls another board out of the box. fascinated by James' obsession.
What's this one from?
(warming to the attention) That was one of our early roadside bombs we disarmed, the one with --
(looking at the board) --it's a piece of junk from Radio Shack.
James shrugs. He reaches over to get the circuit board fr Sanborn, who clearly doesn't share his fascination.
I agree.
In the distance, sound of BOMBS going off. The men pause listen.
The only reason he likes you is because you act like his bitch, and you look up to him, and he likes to be the top dog.
I agree with that too.
Oh no, (picking up James' pistol) The humiliation is too great to bear. (he pulls the trigger while slipping out the clip). Good-bye world.
The gun clicks harmlessly. Eldridge laughs.
A gust of wind rattles the front door.
That punch was harder than I hit you. I'm owed a good one.
Alright.
Hold on, we need some rules. No face shots.
James lifts off his shirt, getting into fighting mode. Eldridge picks up a marker and begins to draw a bulls-eye James' stomach, stopping when he sees a cluster of scars.
Beauty mark, my mother dropped me at birth.
Looks like frag scars.
Sanborn slugs James. James doubles over, loses his balanc and falls back. James gets up, laughing so hard it hurts. Tears of laughter falling down his face.
Ahhhh! Excellent. Now your turn.
Sanborn braces for the blow. James gets ready to strike, fakes a swing -- his fist stops just shy of Sanborn's che
Sanborn's eyes go wide as -- James nails him with his oth hand, right in the gut -- Sanborn doubles over.
Looks like it hurt.
Moving forward aggressively, suddenly James looks like he could kill. A complete change in his demeanor, as wind ro the trailer, causing the light bulb to rattle and cast a STRANGE SHADOW

-- then James rushes Sanborn, tackling him -- they crash the corner of the room -- in a flash James is on top of Sanborn, pinning him -- Sanborn moves to punch James but James pins his hands -- James taps Sanborn lightly on the cheek, caressing his cheek.
There there. It'll be okay.
Get off of me you freak.
Sanborn tries to buck James off. Forcefully raising his h
Oh yeah, ride me, ride me.
Sanborn reaches for his boot knife. He flicks it open, br the blade to James' throat. Their eyes lock. James dismou laughing. Stumbles back to the table.
You're alright, Sanborn. Let's have another.
The wind is blowing harder, kicking up sand. Overhead, a moon is blazing.
James looks up at the moon. It's dazzling. James and Eldr support Sanborn as they weave towards Eldridge's trailer.
I got him.
Eldridge passes Sanborn off to James, and heads up the st to his trailer.
Later.
Sanborn sags. James pulls him back. They walk a little farther to Sanborn's trailer --
Okay. Here we go big boy.
And half carries Sanborn up the steps.
James eases Sanborn onto a cot, and as he falls onto the the WHITE ENVELOPE falls out of his pocket.
Do you think I have what it takes to get in the bomb suit?
James didn't expect this.
Sure.
James picks up the white envelope and puts it on Sanborn' night table.
He looks back. Sanborn is already asleep.
The whole camp is asleep but James is standing outside, holding a satellite phone. He's swaying. Drunk.
James, my God, what time is it? Are you alright.
Pause.
James?
I'm doing fine, babe. How are you?
Well, you woke me up. But - ah - we - we're fine. (getting more lively) Will junior said "bobba" He means bottle, but he's talking, Will.
James looks around the camp. All he sees is its immensity the tremendous scope of the operation. This is military might, raw power. As good as it gets.
Great. I'll call you tomorrow when you're awake.
Will, I can't wait until you come home.
Silence.
Will?
(trying his best to mean
Yeah, me too.
Will you call me again soon?
Sure. Bye honey.
Bye honey.
James hits the END button on the phone and walks up the s to his trailer --

head_text.subj: INT JAMES TRAILER LATER THAT NIGHT

text: He stumbles inside, drops the satellite phone down on his desk, next to his bomb suit helmet, and sinks into bed. H lies there, clothed and awake, and stares at the helmet, looking at his reflection in the polished glass.
Then James reaches over to the helmet and lifts it up, he it.
He puts the helmet on his head.
Alone in his bed, wearing his helmet.
Smiling behind the glass, for he now he can sense the bom and feel his nearness to death.
We hear the RASP of his breathing.
Sanborn blinks awake to a painfully bright sun. He shifts attention to the white envelope on the table.
A SOLDIER wearing glasses is talking to Sanborn.
What can I do for you?
I have something?
Remains?
No.
Personal effects?
Yeah.
Sanborn reaches into his back pocket, withdraws the white envelope. He opens it. Inside are Thompson's DOG TAGS. He crumples the envelope, lets it fall to the floor. And gri the tags tightly.
What's the name?
Thompson, Matt. Sergeant EOD. Baker Company.
(looking at a form) Okay let me see. He's at three- three-eight. (looking) third aisle down the hall.

Sanborn turns to look, and now we see where he's standing the MORTUARY AFFAIRS UNIT, in a large room filled with wh boxes. It looks like an art installation, each white box spaced evenly in a cavernous space.
I'll walk you over there.
They walk down the aisles, passing rows and rows of white boxes, and finally stop.
The soldier opens one.
Inside are a pair of boots. A stack of clothes. Books. Photographs. The remains of a life.
Here you go. Did you know him?
Sanborn places the tags on the uniform in the box.
Yeah, I did. He was my team leader.
Oh, I'm sorry brother.
They walk up the aisles, again passing the rows of white boxes.
At the entrance, Sanborn turns. The soldier offers his ha They shake warmly.
Thank you. Thank you.
The soldier, a little perplexed at Sanborn's gratitude, doesn't know what to say.
Sanborn leaves, notices the empty ENVELOPE on the floor. Litter. He picks it up and stuffs it back into his pocket
James and Eldridge eat in hung-over silence.
Tired.
After a while...
Tough night.
Hell, yeah.
Eldridge nods.
Wind picks up.    The whole tent shakes.
Aren't you supposed to be at your shrink?
I fired him. I said, Doc, shooting a man had a salubrious effect on me.
What the hell does that mean?
Healthy.
You're healthy? Well, why not.
They go back to eating.
Sanborn joins James and Eldridge.
What's up team?
They nod silently as he sits. Sluggishly he throws his ha down on the table.
Can I get a Huu-haa?
Eldridge slaps a tired hand on top of Sanborn's. James follows suit. They wearily lift their arms in mock enthusiasm.
All at once:   "Huu-haa."
Sanborn wolfs down some food.
I'm going back to sleep now.
Let's roll.
They get up to bus their trays. And nearing the dirty-tra bin, the flaps of the tent billow more and more vigorousl Outside, a storm is brewing.
Each man unfurls the checkered scarf around their neck an wraps their face for the wind.
Wind rakes sand and dust over the tent city, giving it an otherworldly aspect. Throngs of men and vehicles fight th swirl. It impedes their every move.
The three men continue onwards, as the intensity of the s grows.
The storm is HOWLING now. Visibility is reduced to a few feet. Red sand blows mercilessly. It's Mars.   TITLE OVER:

head_text.subj: DAYS LEFT IN BRAVO COMPANY'S ROTATION

text: As they approach the head shed, a Humvee comes blasting o of the storm from the other direction. It skids to a halt front of them.
Three wounded EOD TECHS and an EOD TEAM LEADER tumble out

They look awful. One step shy of death. One man's face is smeared brown. Blood oozes from a deep gash in his cheek. Another tech is covered in black soot. Their hands still clutch their weapons -- the battle still wages in their minds.

(shouting to James) It was a car bomb. Fucking nasty one -- they had a decoy detonator set up so that when I disarmed it nothing happened -- then, I'm walking back uprange to get some more tools and boooom!!! If I hadn't been wearing the suit, I'd be dead right now.
Get a Medic to look at your cheek.
The wounded TEAM LEADER touches his face and blood smears his hand...he looks down...surreal to see your own blood. The First Sergeant trots over.
(amazed at the sight of
It's no big deal. (now turning his attention back to James) ) Be careful. They're starting to hide the detonator really well.
The FIRST SERGEANT turns his attention to James:
Sorry to ruin your day off, but your team is up.
James blinks back sand and dust blowing into his eyes.
So much for the nap.

head_text.subj: INT HUMVEE CAMP VICTORY PARKING LOT

text: Lt. COL. CAMBRIDGE knocks on the window. Startling the me His face appears in the sand storm.
Are you guys about to go out?
Yeah.
Mind if I ride along? I'm sick to death of sitting behind a desk all the time.
James shoots Eldridge a look.   Eldridge shrugs.
Anytime, Sir. It's a privilege.
The LT. COL. CAMBRIDGE gets in. As they drive out.
Don't mean to insult your intelligence, Sir. But if the shit hits the fan, please don't fire out of these windows. They're bullet proof and the round will just bounce around the cabin.

head_text.subj: EXT. ABU GRAIB CENTER BOMBED OUT BUILDING DAY

text: A partially destroyed building fills the screen. A mess o bricks and rebar. Wind swirls sand up into the air.
Nearby, an OLD IRAQI MAN with a DONKEY drawn cart is unloading new bricks to repair the building.
Farther up the road, a good distance from the building, a two parked Humvees. Nearby, James and his team are talkin a small cluster of SOLDIERS.
(pointing back at the
Right up those stairs.
You been inside already?
In there? Fuck no. We've had reports of all kinds of shit coming out of that house -- and--
James takes his eyes off the building and turns to the Soldier.
--bodies.
James turns to Cambridge.
Why don't you wait here? We'll bring out anything of interest.

head_text.subj: INT BOMBED OUT BUILDING LATE MORNING

text: James, Sanborn and Eldridge enter a landing. The floor is very wet. They cross it, and come to a room that has been severely damaged by a bomb, with rubble everywhere and exposed electrical wires dangling from the ceiling, and busted pipes gushing water.
A tea pot sits on a STOVE, steaming hot, and a plate on t table has bread on it.
James bends the gushing pipe, stemming the flow of water trickle. Now the spitting wire hanging above the water pi looks less ominous. But not by much.   CORRIDOR
They continue down a narrow corridor, light diminishing. switch on the lights on their M4s. The corridor ends at a door.
This would be a great place to put a pressure activator.
Yeah, with like twenty pounds of high explosives on it so you get anyone in the room when you open the door.
Rope trick?
Eldridge uncoils rope from his pack and hands it to James who makes a lasso and tosses it over the doorknob.
James yanks the rope -- we follow the rope inside through kitchen to the doorknob, watching it turn. No bomb.
They head back in.
Ascending a staircase. James unstraps a flash grenade fro his vest and heaves it onto the floor above. They stick their fingers in their ears...
Blinding FLASH and DEAFENING sound. Then silence.   No movement.
Guess no one's home.
Blaster One, what was that?
Sorry, one of ours, just a flash grenade.
They come to a landing that opens up to the second floor.   SECOND FLOOR

A large cavernous space filled with what looks like Santa bomb making factory: A pile of motherboards. Batteries. B boxes. Electronics in various states of disassembly. In another corner, stacks of artillery shells. Blocks of C4 plastic explosives.

In the back half of the room, there is a   work table, an the table is a DEAD BODY of a young man,   wearing pants shirt. A JACKET draped is over its torso   and face. Even these hardened EOD experts, the sight is   unnerving, and copper smell of spilt blood and death is   staggering, sickening.
James, Sanborn and Eldridge approach the body cautiously.
James pulls a retractable aluminum pole from his pack and telescopes it to its maximum length, about 10 feet, and u the pole to lift the jacket. Gently. The FACE appears.

All that we can determine about this face is that it is young. The distinguishing lines of the nose and cheeks ar covered by bruises and blood and further obscured by the shadows and dappled light, that it could be the face of almost any young man.
The violence done to the face exerts an odd pull on James
The kid at camp.
What?
He sells DVDs.
No, that's not him.
You see him every day. He sells DVDs by the mess tent. His name is Pele.
Different kid.
This is sick.

The dead young man's chest has been cut open. An artiller shell is shoved inside the cavity where the heart used to beat. Wires protrude from the shell. It's meant to be a b trap, to be placed on a street and elicit as much damage possible.
You seen a body bomb before?
James shakes his head no.
Sanborn moves closer to the body and inspects the wiring the chest.
Don't touch it. Let's blow it.   JAMES
Positioning three blocks of C4 on the body, then plugs blasting caps into the explosives. James nods to Sanborn Eldridge, and they leave him alone with the body.
James walks backwards out of the room, unspooling a roll detonation cord as he goes. But before he gets to the doo
Blaster, we've got a hold. I'm not getting airspace clearance.
Copy that, How long?
Roger. Could be anything. At least 15 minutes is what they're saying.
Can you -- you need to explain to them that we don't have 15 minutes.
Roger. I'll see if we can push this ahead.
James squats down, rests his rifle, looks at the floor.
Moments pass and he feels a set of eyes on him.
He swivels his head to the left and makes eye contact wit the dead kid on the table. The face doesn't have any of t markers of death; it looks alive.
James turns away, then is compelled to make eye contact again. He looks at his watch. The seconds tick by all too slowly. He grabs his walkie-talkie.
Fifteen is not going to work. I need to do this now.
Roger, I understand. If it was me, I would go for it, but I don't think command is going to budge under the circumstances.
Tell command I'm in a fucking war zone. And I'm going to blow now.
James gets up, clips his rifle, and takes the last few st out of the room.
Blaster One, I don't know who you know, but you got your permission. Ready to det any time you say so.
At the door he stops to look at the dead boy on the table looks and looks. Finally:
Cancel that det.
JAMES
Reaching over the body of the boy. He pulls the artillery shell out of the boy's abdomen with his bare hands. He wi his hands on his pants.
This is Blaster One, I'm coming down.
James carries the body down the staircase. The head and f bump the sides of the staircase as he descends.

head_text.subj: EXT BOMBED OUT BUILDING MOMENTS LATER

text: The BODY lies on the street, James standing over it. A bl and white pickup TRUCK emblazoned with the logo of the Ir National Police pulls up to their position.
A pair of POLICEMEN get out and after a few words with Ja they load the body.     HUMVEE
Sanborn and Eldridge sit across from each other, watching James.
...So you really don't think it was the DVD kid?
No, I don't.
You're positive?
Yeah. Could it be? One in a million chance.
I don't know. Will seemed positive. But that was weird.
Very weird.
They look out the window and notice Lt. Colonel Cambridge down the street surrounded by a crowd of IRAQI MEN.   CAMBRIDGE
Cambridge is trying to talk to several of them at once.
This is not a safe area for you. Imshee!
They don't leave. Cambridge lifts his rifle, not quite shouldering it. Then one MAN, mid thirties, in a suit, st forward.
Why do you talk to us like children. We are not children.
Gimme a break, will you?
Why should I?
Cambridge, suddenly not so sure of himself, looks back to Humvee and sees --   JAMES
Watching the police truck drive away. He then moves for t Humvee, motioning for Cambridge to load up.   INT   HUMVEE
Eldridge guzzles some water.    Wipes sweat from his brow
But then Will's pretty weird. He keeps bomb parts under his bed.
Passing the water to Sanborn.
I bet you he doesn't put this one under his bed.
Sanborn laughs.
James cracks the door, jumps inside.
He sees Cambridge walk past the brick pile that the OLD I MAN had created. The man is no longer there. Something crosses his mind when--
--The brick pile explodes in a A SICKENING BLAST, obliterating Cambridge and flipping the Humvee
--James, Sanborn and Eldridge SPIN upside down as the Hum is buffeted by the blast - landing upside down.
--Suddenly CAMBRIDGE'S helmeted HEAD crashes into the windshield.
--Billowing smoke, dirt and debris smears the windshield blotting out the sun.
--Inside, a flurry of HANDS yank on the heavy armored Hum door. It doesn't budge.   EXT   HUMVEE
A SOLDIER runs to the rescue. He reaches for the Humvee d the metal sears his hand, and he pulls back in pain.
The soldier uses his rifle butt to jam the door open - bu that doesn't work, because the butt doesn't catch the han From inside, the POUNDING and YELLS grow louder.
The soldier drops the rifle and grabs the searing metal w his hand, burning his flesh as he pries the handle.
The Humvee door finally gives. Three men tumble out onto blackened sand.
James is standing in the doorway into the building, divid his attention between the outside and the interior -- whe Sanborn and Eldridge are slumped against a wall.

Sanborn stares at a blank wall. Eldridge is running his h over a cigarette lighter -- seeing how much of the flame can bear. He looks as if he's hoping the physical pain wi help put the psychic pain in perspective.
James, standing in the light of the doorway, is smolderin with rage and ungovernable purpose. He's smoking.
We stay here for a moment to watch as each man makes his deal with himself.
Through the open doorway a Humvee comes into view.
James stomps out his cigarette.
Our ride is here.
Beat.
Sanborn and Eldridge remain in a trance.
We're movin'.
He walks out into the glare. Sanborn and Eldridge rise to follow him.
Funnel of wind erases a tank tread in the sand.
More sand drifts and piles like snow up against a small mountain of sand bags.
Sand disappears the windshield of a parked Abrams as day moves into night.

head_text.subj: EXT CAMP VICTORY MESS TENT MORNING

text: Dust. Wind.
James is stalking towards an OLDER IRAQI MAN who is selli DVDs at Pele's usual table.
Hey - you haven't seen that kid around here by any chance - who sells movies?
The man shakes his head.
Sorry. No English.
No English? Don't lie to me. Where's that kid?
Sorry, my man. Movie? Five dollars.
James shakes his head and walks away, heading towards a c of SOLDIERS standing in the shade of a tree.
Are you guys responsible for this area?
What's up?
That motherfucker over there (pointing to the Man) could be an insurgent, watching the camp and giving intel to his buddies so they know where to launch their mortars.
I think he's just a guy selling DVDs.
He's a security risk. You should get rid of him.
The merchants are cleared. I couldn't do anything to him without the say-so from my CO.
James realizes that he has no hope of prevailing. Agitate he turns away, and we stay with him as he trudges down on Victory's dusty roads.

head_text.subj: EXT. CAMP VICTORY MESS TENT DUSK

text: It's the end of the day and the DVD seller packs up his w to go.
James, in sunglasses, sweatshirt covering his army fatigu follows him to his car. James draws near, and points his pistol at the guy's crotch.
Does this change anything?
The DVD man looks stunned.

head_text.subj: INT DVD MAN'S CAR CAMP VICTORY GATE DUSK

text: James leans across the DVD man and flashes his ID to one two GUARDs.
OGA.
The guard looks to his buddy who mouths "CIA"
Are you cleared to leave the camp through this gate, Sir?
James nods.
I'm going to need to see your ID again.
Don't fuck with me man, I'm having a bad day already.
The guard stares at James. James stares at the guard. The guard shrugs, waves James through.
The truck goes down a series of streets. It comes into a neighborhood and stops at a house.
Pele.
Wait here.
James gets out.
The dwelling is set back behind a low wall. Hard to see m of it in the dim light.
James takes a step forward, toward the wall.  SUDDENLY--
the DVD truck peels out.
James looks at its retreating tail lights. A moment of indecision as he considers his situation: alone in Baghda
Then he vaults the low wall, landing in
A modest courtyard. Light comes from one window in the ho the rest is dark. Crickets.
James walks around to the back of the house. There's a do He tries the knob. It opens.
In a dark hallway. Murmuring of a television. James moves towards the noise.
James comes to an antechamber. Behind it is a very low st archway. He goes through the archway, where -
A MAN -- call him Kalim -- older, fifties, dressed in traditional garb, sits at a table drinking tea, watching Egyptian game show on television.
James walks in, gun drawn.
The man is spooked. He spills his tea, looks wildly for a exit.
James puts his fingers to his lips.
Do you speak English?
English, French, Arabic.
I want the people responsible for Pele.
For whom?
Pele. The body bomb.
Pele? I don't know. But please sit down. I am professor Kalim, this is my home. You are a guest. Sit.
Take me to the people responsible.
Of course, whatever you seek, I will help you find. Please, please sit, down. You are CIA, no? I am very pleased to have CIA in my home.
James raises his gun to aim at the man's face.
Maybe you don't understand?
The man is suddenly very afraid.
Please, be careful. Be slow. A gun can go off.
As the back door opens
-- James spins to see
-- a WOMAN, older, matronly. She sees James, his gun. And starts shouting at James in Arabic, then English, "Get ou get out."
James swings his gun to her.  SUDDENLY--
-- behind the woman comes Pele. He runs to his father's s
-- James turns to the boy, to say something --
-- his mother is rushing James now, swinging a candlestic
-- he spins to the door, trying to get out of there --
-- SMASHING his head on the stone archway on his way out.
-- the street.
James is shaken. He looks around, down the street. It's murky. Dangerous. Even the shadows have shadows.
He runs...and runs...and we stay on his eyes. Blood runs the wound on his head.
SOUND of far off EXPLOSION. The sky turns orange briefly, then fades into blackness.
A blast of bright white light floods James. He's stunned and raises his ID in his open palm over his head. A scrap blood stained fabric is wrapped around his head wound.
Multiple rifles suddenly trained on his upturned face. VO SLAP CONCRETE:
On your knees, on your knees!!
A big offish GUARD walks up and slams a rifle butt into t side of James' head.
He falls to the ground.
What're you doing?
Ficke, ficke.
The guard sees the military ID splayed on the ground.
Yeah?
James nods.
